properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "In 2015, record warm surface temperatures were observed for the global mean, India, and the equatorial central Pacific. CMIP5 simulations suggest that for the globe and India, anthropogenic warming was largely to blame."
properties.authors: Kam et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S61-S65

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "In 2015, record warm surface temperatures were observed for the global mean, India, and the equatorial central Pacific. CMIP5 simulations suggest that for the globe and India, anthropogenic warming was largely to blame."
properties.authors: Kam et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S61-S65

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Station-based observations and bias-corrected model simulations show that the frequency of short-term heat waves in central Europe has increased, albeit quantitative estimates of risk ratios differ considerably between methods."
properties.authors: Sippel et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S51-S56

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "A heat wave swept across central Europe in summer 2015. Model experiments suggest that anthropogenic forcings were a major factor in setting the conditions for the development of the 2015 heat wave."
properties.authors: Dong et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S57-S62

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "A combined modeling and observational assessment of the 2015 heat wave in Egypt found that human discomfort increased due to anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Mitchell (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S70-S74

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic warming contributed to the 2015 Ethiopian and southern African droughts by increasing El Niño SSTs and local air temperatures, causing reduced rainfall and runoff, and contributing to severe food insecurity."
properties.authors: Funk et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S75-S80

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "We find that the deadly heat waves in India and Pakistan in 2015 were exacerbated by anthropogenic climate change. Although the impacts of both events were severe, the events themselves were not connected to each other."
properties.authors: Wehner et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S81-S86

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The record-breaking heat over northwest China in July 2015 was linked directly to atmospheric general circulation indices and anthropogenic forcing. The latter increased the risk of extreme heat by three-fold."
properties.authors: Miao et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S97-S101

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Human influence has very likely increased the probability of occurrence of the 2015 western China extreme summer temperature events by at least 3-fold and 42-fold for the highest daily maximum and minimum temperatures, respectively.
properties.authors: Sun et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S102-S106

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The persistent Japanese heat wave that occurred in early August 2015 was mainly attributed to intraseasonal disturbances including tropical cyclones. Anthropogenic warming contributed to an increase in the probability of occurrence.
properties.authors: Takahashi et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S107-S112

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "El Niño and human-induced climate change have substantially increased the likelihood of rainfall deficits and high temperatures, respectively, in Indonesia such as those experienced in the drought conditions of July–October 2015."
properties.authors: King et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S113-S117

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic climate change was found to have a substantial influence on southern Australia’s extreme heat in October 2015. The relative influence of El Niño conditions was less clear."
properties.authors: Black et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S118-S121

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Using a seasonal forecasting framework for attribution, we find that half of the record heat anomaly across Australia in October 2015 can be attributed to increasing CO2, with much of the rest due to internal atmospheric variability."
properties.authors: Hope et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S122-126

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Extreme winter sunshine in the United Kingdom, as observed in the record high 2014/15 season, has become more than 1.5 times more likely to occur under the influence of anthropogenic forcings."
properties.authors: Christidis et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S47-S50

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic activity has increased the risk of Australian heatwaves during late autumn similar to the 2014 event by up to 23-fold, compared to climate conditions under no anthropogenic influence."
properties.authors: Perkins & Gibson (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S154-S157

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "According to CMIP5 models, the risk of record annual mean warmth in European, northeast Pacific, and northwest Atlantic regions—as occurred in 2014—has been greatly increased by anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Kam et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S61-S65

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "A comparison of observations and multiple global climate models indicates human influence has increased the chance of extreme hot springs in Korea such as the 2014 event by two to three times."
properties.authors: Min et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S95-99

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic climate change very likely increased the likelihood of prolonged heat waves like that experienced in Adelaide in January 2014 by at least 16%. The influence for Melbourne is less clear."
properties.authors: Black et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S145-S148

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Climate model simulations for 2014 indicate anthropogenic climate change very likely increased the likelihood of hot and very hot November days in Brisbane by at least 25% and 44% respectively."
properties.authors: King et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S141-S144

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The Argentinian heat wave of December 2013 was likely caused in part by anthropogenic forcings. These forcings have increased the risk of such an event occurring by a factor of five."
properties.authors: Hannart, A. et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12),S41-45

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Record high September maximum temperatures over Australia arose from a combination of a strongly anomalous atmospheric circulation pattern, background warming, and dry and warm antecedent land-surface conditions."
properties.authors: Arblaster et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S37-S41

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The record heat of 2013 across inland eastern Australia was caused by a combination of anthropogenic warming and extreme drought."
properties.authors: King et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S41-S45

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "CMIP5 simulations suggest that the extremely warm year observed over Australia and the far western Pacific during 2013 was largely attributable to human forcing of the climate system."
properties.authors: Knutson et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S26-30

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic climate change has caused a very large increase in the likelihood of extreme events such as the record Australia-wide average temperatures in September, spring, and the 2013 calendar year."
properties.authors: Lewis et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S31-S34

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Human activity has increased the risk of experiencing the hot Australian summer of 2012/13, as measured by simulated heat wave frequency and intensity, by two- and three-fold, respectively."
properties.authors: Perkins et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S34-S37

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic forcing played a substantial part in western Europe’s hot, dry summer in 2013. North Atlantic sea surface temperatures were likely a factor in the large contrast with summer 2012."
properties.authors: Dong et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S62-S66

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Comparison based on Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) models suggest a discernible impact of anthropogenic forcing, with internal variability also being important."
properties.authors: Zhou et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S54-57

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic climate change played a significant role in increasing the probability of events such as the heat wave in Japan in 2013."
properties.authors: Imada et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S52-54

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "A comparison of observations and multiple global climate model simulations indicates that extreme hot summer temperatures in Korea have become 10 times more likely due to human influence."
properties.authors: Min et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S48-S51

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Our analyses of the CMIP5 global climate model ensemble suggest that the likelihood of extreme July temperature anomalies is greater in the current forcing than in the preindustrial forcing."
properties.authors: Diffenbaugh & Scherer (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S6-S9

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The degree of decadal variability in these features suggests a role for forcing from outside the dynamical atmosphere, and preliminary numerical experiments suggest that the global SST and low Arctic sea ice extent anomalies are likely to have played a role."
properties.authors: Dong et al. (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S28-S32

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Therefore, a cold December of –0.7°C is half as likely to occur in the 2000s when compared to the 1960s."
properties.authors: Massey et al., (2012) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., S1057-S1059

properties.location: United Kingdom, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Germany and Switzerland
properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "We estimate it is very likely (confidence level >90%) that human influence has at least doubled the risk of a heatwave exceeding this threshold magnitude."
properties.authors: Stott et al., (2004) Nature, 432, 610-614

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "For July temperature in Moscow, we estimate...an approximate 80% probability that the 2010 July heat record would not have occurred without climate warming."
properties.authors: Rahmstorf & Coumou (2011) PNAS, 108 (44), 17905.

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.authors: Sun et al., (2014) Nature Climate Change, 4, 1082-1085

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "With 90% confidence we find that anthropogenic forcings on the climate have increased the chances of record warm years in Central England by at least 13-fold."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The likelihood of a given unusually high summer temperature being exceeded was simulated to be about 10 times greater due to anthropogenic emissions."
properties.authors: Rupp et al., (2015) Geophysical Research Letters, 42 (7), 2392–2400

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "The anthropogenic contribution to the extreme seasonal (MAM) warmth over the eastern United States can be estimated as about 35%, or in terms of risk, anthropogenic forcing leads to a factor of 12 increase in the risk of such an event according to our calculations."

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.authors: Trenberth et al., (2012) Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, D17103

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "Despite severe cold waves and record-breaking extreme cold-day occurrences during 2015, no long-term increase in winter daily temperature extremes has occurred in the eastern United States—winters have become warmer and less variable."
properties.authors: Trenary et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S31-S35

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "The near-record number of extremely cold days during winter 2014 in the eastern United States cannot be attributed to trends or variability changes. Daily temperature variability is actually decreasing, in contrast to CMIP5 simulations and projections."

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "Snowfall on the thin ice that had just formed is shown to limit the ice growth more strongly than the effect of warming."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic warming contributed to the 2015 Ethiopian and southern African droughts by increasing local air temperatures and El Niño sea surface temperatures, causing reduced rainfall and runoff, and contributing to severe food insecurity."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The 2014/15 snowpack drought resulted from exceedingly high temperatures notwithstanding normal precipitation—a drought type that may reoccur due to accelerated anthropogenic warming and aggravated by naturally driven low precipitation."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Anthropogenic warming contributed to the 2014 East African drought by increasing East African and west Pacific temperatures, and increasing the gradient between standardized western and central Pacific SST causing reduced rainfall, evapotranspiration, and soil moisture."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Ensemble modelling of the East African 2014 long rains season suggests no anthropogenic influence on the likelihood of low rainfall but clear signals in other drivers of drought."
properties.authors: Marthews et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S83-S88

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "A combined modeling and observational study suggests that the persistent rainfall deficit during the 2014 rainy season in southern Levant was made more likely due to anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Bergaoui et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S66-S70

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "For the 2013 New Zealand drought, evidence from a number of models suggests that the meteorological drivers were more favorable for drought as a result of anthropogenic climate change."

properties.authors: Trigo et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S41-S45

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.authors: Mann & Gleick (2015) Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 112 (13), 3858-3859

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century."

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.authors: Funk et al., (2012) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., S1049-S1051

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive

properties.authors: Singh et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S58-S61

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "This suggests a contribution of climate change to precipitation rate in northern Europe. We conjecture that such a trend could be due to precipitation rates within the cyclonic patterns, which convey more moisture because of increased temperatures."
properties.authors: Yiou et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S39-S41

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "This analysis indicates that the total moisture available for precipitation in the Golden Bay/Nelson extreme rainfall event of December 2011 was 1%–5% higher as a result of the emission of anthropogenic greenhouse gases."
properties.authors: Dean et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S61-S63

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "For all but one catchment, emissions are likely to have led to an increased chance of flooding in the October–December period."
properties.authors: Kay et al., (2011) Journal of Hydrology, 406 (1-2), 97-112

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "In nine out of ten cases our model results indicate that twentieth-century anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions increased the risk of floods occurring in England and Wales in autumn 2000 by more than 20%, and in two out of three cases by more than 90%"
properties.authors: Pall et al., (2011) Nature, 470, 382-385

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "In nine out of ten cases our model results indicate that twentieth-century anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions increased the risk of floods occurring in England and Wales in autumn 2000 by more than 20%, and in two out of three cases by more than 90%"
properties.authors: Pall et al., (2011) Nature, 470, 382-385

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur
properties.summary: "The probability for an extreme five-day September rainfall event over northeast Colorado, as was observed in early September 2013, has likely decreased due to climate change."
properties.authors: Hoerling et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S15-S18

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "We find no evidence that the delayed onset of the wet season over Nigeria during April–May 2015 was made more likely by anthropogenic influences or anomalous sea surface temperatures. "
properties.authors: Lawal et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S63-69

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "Extreme one-day rainfall caused widespread flooding in Chennai, India, in December 2015. No effect of global warming was detected, likely caused by aerosols counteracting greenhouse gases up to now."
properties.authors: van Oldenborgh et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S87-S91

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "An observation-based analysis and large simulation ensembles show no evidence that climate change made heavy precipitation in the upper Danube and Elbe basins in May–June, such as observed in 2013, more likely."
properties.authors: Schaller et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S69-S72

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "The implication is that human alteration of the atmospheric composition may have had little effect on the frequency of low-precipitation periods."
properties.authors: Rupp et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S2-S6

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "We find no evidence that declines in sea ice can explain these recent wet summers, with the expected response to changes in sea ice since the late 1980s being small."
properties.authors: Tett et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S32-S35

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "Although the summer UK rainfall in 2012 was unusually large, the model distributions studied suggest that any anthropogenic influence on these patterns was minimal."
properties.authors: Sparrow et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S36-S38

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "In summary, we detect limited evidence of a change in the relationship between ENSO and SE Australia extreme rainfall, or of a change in extreme rainfall itself, that may be attributed to anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: King et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S55-S58

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "Neither in the precipitation observations nor in climate models is there a trend in mean or variability up to now, so climate change cannot be shown to have played any role in this event."
properties.authors: van Oldenborgh et al., (2012) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., S1047-S1049

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "The January 2014 floods paralyzed nearly all of Jakarta, Indonesia. The precipitation events that lead to these floods were not very unusual but show positive trends in the observed record."
properties.authors: Siswanto et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S131-S135

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "Extreme winter rainfall in the United Kingdom becomes eight times more likely when the atmospheric circulation resembles winter 2013/14, whereas anthropogenic influence is only discernible in extremes with a shorter duration."
properties.authors: Cristidis et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S46-S50

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "Extreme daily fall precipitation in the Cévennes mountains has very likely intensified. The probability of amounts witnessed in 2014 is estimated to have tripled since 1950, with large uncertainties."
properties.authors: Vautard et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S56-S60

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "Winter 2013 was the second wettest since 1948 in southern Europe. This is partially explained by the atmospheric circulation. We suspect the warm Atlantic Ocean to have amplified the precipitation extreme."
properties.authors: Yiou & Cattiaux (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S66-S69

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "We are unable to confirm or reject the role of climate change in the 21–22 July 2012 rainfall event due to the inability of the CMIP5 models to accurately replicate observations in this region of China."
properties.authors: Zhou et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S49-S51

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "In the case of the 2012 event, the effect of anthropogenic global warming is too small to be detected compared with the variability due to the natural variability of the SST."
properties.authors: Imada et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S52-S54

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "Despite the potential contribution of all factors examined here, the extreme magnitude of the event appears to arise mainly from unforced internal climatic variations."
properties.authors: Christidis et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S58-S61

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The extreme value of the 2015 western North Pacific (WNP) accumulated cyclone energy (ACE) was mainly caused by the sea surface warming in the eastern and central Pacific, with the anthropogenic forcing largely increasing the odds of the occurrence of this event."
properties.authors: Zhang et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S131-S135

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "New climate simulations suggest that the extremely active 2014 Hawaiian hurricane season was made substantially more likely by anthropogenic forcing, but that natural variability of El Niño was also partially involved."
properties.authors: Murakami et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S115-S119

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "After transitioning from a hurricane to an extratropical storm, Gonzalo tracked unusually far, achieving exceptional strength over Europe; however, it was within the historical range of such transforming storms."
properties.authors: Feser et al, (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S51-55

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "The absence of western North Pacific tropical cyclone activity during August 2014 was apparently related to strong easterly wind anomalies induced by combined negative intraseasonal and Pacific decadal oscillation phases."
properties.authors: Yang et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S120-S125

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The 2015 Alaska fire season burned the second largest number of acres since records began in 1940. Human-induced climate change may have increased the risk of a fire season of this severity by 34%–60%."
properties.authors: Partain et al. (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S14-S18

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The fire season in northern California during 2014 was the second largest in terms of burned areas since 1996. An increase in fire risk in California is attributable to human-induced climate change."
properties.authors: Yoon et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S5-S9

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The record low Northern Hemisphere (NH) winter sea ice maximum stemmed from a strong interannual surface anomaly in the Pacific sector, but it would not have been reached without long-term climate change."
properties.authors: Fučkar et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S136-S140

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Our modeling results indicate that the exceptional 2012 sea ice loss was primarily due to the sea ice memory and to the positive feedback of the warm atmospheric conditions, both contributing approximately equally."
properties.authors: Guemas et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S20-S22

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The observed 2012 record low in ASIE is extremely unlikely to have occurred due to internal climate variability alone, according to the models."
properties.authors: Zhang & Knutson (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S23-S26

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur
properties.summary: "An early October blizzard in South Dakota is determined to be climatologically anomalous. Climate models suggest that early autumn extreme snowfall events in western South Dakota are less likely due to anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Edwards et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S23-S26

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "Natural climatic variability was apparently the main driver in the extreme cumulative snowfall that fell in the Pyrenees in 2013."
properties.authors: Anel et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S73-S76

properties.impact_description: Insufficient data/inconclusive
properties.summary: "The record maximum of Antarctic sea ice resulted chiefly from anomalous winds that transported cold air masses away from the Antarctic continent, enhancing thermodynamic sea ice production far offshore."
properties.authors: Massonnet et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S163-S167

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The probability of a 0.57-m tidal flood within the Miami region has increased by >500% since 1994 from a 10.9-cm sea level rise (SLR)-related trend in monthly highest tides."
properties.authors: Sweet et al., (2016) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 97 (12), S25-S30

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "CMIP5 models suggest that human influence has increased the probability of regional high SST extremes over the western tropical and northeast Pacific Ocean during the 2014 calendar year and summer."
properties.authors: Weller et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S100-S104

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "According to CMIP5 models, the risk of record annual mean warmth in European, northeast Pacific, and northwest Atlantic regions—as occurred in 2014—has been greatly increased by anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Kam et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S61-S65

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "It is likely that human influences on climate increased the odds of the extreme high pressure anomalies south of Australia in August 2014 that were associated with frosts, lowland snowfalls and reduced rainfall."
properties.authors: Grose et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S158-S162

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "Accordingly, we estimate that relative sea level over 1950–2012 from global SLR (thermal expansion and ice melt), VLM (subsidence), and ocean circulation variability has contributed to a one- to two-thirds decrease in Sandy-level event recurrences."
properties.authors: Sweet et al., (2013) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 94 (9), S17-S20

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The Himalayan snowstorm of October 2014 resulted from the unusual merger of a tropical cyclone with an upper trough, and their collective changes under climate warming have increased the odds for similar events."
properties.authors: Wang et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S89-94

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "The extreme 2013/14 winter storm season over much of North America was made more likely by the multiyear anomalous tropical Pacific winds associated with the recent global warming hiatus."
properties.authors: Yang et al. (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S25-S28

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "The all-time record number of storms over the British Isles in winter 2013/14 cannot be linked directly to anthropogenic-induced warming of the tropical west Pacific."
properties.authors: Wild et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S29-34

properties.impact_description: No discernible human influence
properties.summary: "A strong storm on 28 October 2013 over northern Germany and southern Denmark fits a slight increase in storminess during recent decades. However, the increase constitutes part of multidecadal variability."
properties.authors: von Storch et al., (2014) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 95 (9), S76-S78

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.authors: van de Wiel et al., (2017) Hydrology and Earth System Sciences, 21, 897-921

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The difference in conclusion between these two papers illustrates the importance of specifying precisely what question is being asked in addressing the issue of attribution of individual weather events to external drivers of climate."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. Less severe or less likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "The result indicates that the worst case scenario of a storm surge in the Gulf of Leyte may be worse by 20%, though changes in frequency of such events are not accounted for here."

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "In a large ensemble of climate model simulations, we find that, as well as increasing the amount of moisture the atmosphere can hold, anthropogenic warming caused a small but significant increase in the number of January days with westerly flow, both of which increased extreme precipitation."
properties.authors: Schaller et al., (2016) Nature Climate Change, 6,  627–634

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "According to CMIP5 models, the risk of record annual mean warmth in European, northeast Pacific, and northwest Atlantic regions—as occurred in 2014—has been greatly increased by anthropogenic climate change."
properties.authors: Kam et al., (2015) Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc., 96 (12), S61-S65

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "It was suggested that both the anthropogenic warming and an atmospheric circulation regime related to the natural variability of SST and SIC made the heat wave event more likely."
properties.authors: Shiogama et al., (2014) JSTage:SOLA, 10, 122-126

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "[A] long-term warming trend likely contributed to surface moisture deficits during the drought. As such, the precipitation deficit during the drought was dominated by natural variability."
properties.authors: Seager et al., (2015)

properties.impact_description: Yes. More severe or more likely to occur
properties.summary: "We find that historical warming has increased the severity and probability of the hottest month and hottest day of the year at >80% of the available observational area."
